captions.text:
Pretty much everything in the universe is
made out of matter - the earth, air, you and

me, stars, interstellar dust - all matter.
By which we mean that these things are made

out of electrons and quarks - and very occasionally
other rarer matter particles like muons, tauons,
and neutrinos.

All of these particles are, at their fundamental
level, excitations in everywhere-permeating

quantum fields. But, as the famous quote goes,
“for every particle, there is an equal and

opposite antiparticle - an opposite excitation
in the everywhere permeating quantum field

that has all of the exact same properties
as that particle - except opposite charge.”

And since these antiparticles are opposite
excitations of the quantum field, when a particle

and antiparticle meet, they annihilate and
destroy each other!

Which is pretty much exactly like how the
equation x^2=4 has two solutions: 2 and -2,

with the same value but opposite sign. And
when they meet, they annihilate!

Every fundamental particle has an antiparticle:
there are antiquarks, antineutrinos, antimuons,

antitauons, and of course antielectrons - though
we call them positrons.

Since antimatter particles are essentially
identical to regular matter other than the

opposite charge thing, they can combine together
in essentially identical ways to form antiprotons,

anti-atoms, anti-molecules, and, in principle,
anything from anti-ants to anti-matterhorns.

Except 
because every particle of antimatter annihilates
with regular matter upon meeting, it’s really

hard to make anything big out of antimatter
- at this point we’re still only able to

contain a few hundred antihydrogen atoms at
one time. But we can also make the really

cool positronium atom - it’s like hydrogen,
except instead of an electron orbiting a proton,

it’s an electron orbiting a POSITRON. Until
they annihilate each other in under a nanosecond.

And when they annihilate, the energy of particle
and antiparticle has to go somewhere, which

is why matter/antimatter annihilations have
been proposed as bombs. But naturally-occuring

antimatter is hard to come by. So, unlike
a uranium fission bomb, which allow us to

release the bottled energy of the supernovas
that forged the uranium in the first place,

you’d have to put all the energy into an
antimatter bomb yourself by making antimatter.

Which you do by agitating empty space into
pairs of matter and antimatter excitations.

Kind of like hitting zero with a hammer to
get out 2 and minus 2, except instead of a

hammer, you use a particle accelerator or
high-energy photons of light.

Photons, incidentally, have zero charge and
so are their OWN antiparticles, in the same
way that zero is equal to negative zero!

In fact, mathematics has always been closely
tied to antimatter: the mathematics of relativisitic

quantum mechanics predicted the existence
of antimatter before any had ever been discovered.

The fact that there’s so little antimatter
around in the universe TO discover is both

an obvious thing (because if it were around,
it would have destroyed us), a good thing

(because it can’t destroy us), and a puzzling
thing - if matter and antimatter are basically

identical “mirror” images of one another,
why did the big bang produce so much more
matter than antimatter?

No one knows - though to physicists, the answer
matters.

comments.author: Eric Lundberg

comments.text:
Physicists are puzzled about how is it possible that the whole universe we 
observe is made out of matter while any excitation of the Higgs Field 
creates equal amounts of matter and anti-matter, and the most widely 
accepted answer is "there was somehow a little bit more matter than anti 
matter at the start of the show," but what if the anti-matter is hiding in 
plain sight?  The space between galaxies is vast, perhaps vast enough that 
perhaps matter somehow sorted out in large enough or dense enough 
formations of either type to create galaxies and anti-galaxies. Perhaps 
half our galaxies are anti-matter.﻿

present math does not quite conform to reality.

comments.author: Justin A

comments.text:
The reason for space having 'no' temperature is because there are little 
atoms in space to be heated up and thus causing nothing to be heated up. 
The opposite goes for planets with an atmosphere, the atmosphere becomes 
heats (as in the elements in the atmosphere "Carbon Dioxide, Nitrogen, 
Oxygen, etc.") Pretty much all planets and celecial bodies have an 
atmosphere but some not a defined one such as mars or the moon. So, space 
doesn't really have "no" temperature, but there is hardly any heat energy 
in most of space in between stars ans such and that is also why things get 
cold in space (if not near a nearby star of course) because the heat energy 
of the object and the space around it wants to even out and that is why the 
heat is taken from the object and it becomes as cold as the space around it.

+Giannis Polychronopoulos Einstein's equation implies negative energy. E^2 
= m^2 * c^4 + p^2 * c^2
When you apply a square root, you have to consider both positive and 
negative answers, so 

E = +/- square root(m^2 * c^4 + p^2 *c^2)
Not that we actually have found any of it, however.

+Bobert Johnson neutrons have neutral charge *in total*, but it's made out 
of quarks that have charge, and not symmetrically -- two down-quarks (-1/3 
each) cancel out the charge of a single up-quark (+2/3) to make a neutron. 
An anti-neutron would be made out of two anti-down-quarks plus a single 
anti-up-quark.

+orly4672 My pardons. I mistook them. Neutrinos have mass. This suggests

possiblity of electromagnetic reactions between neutrinos. While I, myself, 
a humble mind from the internet, can't speculate or guess close enough, my 
guess is that this information has something to do with it. It is also 
worth mentioning that the only way known to naturally form anti-neutrinos 
is via nuclear beta decay. Also, it is very much possible there is no such 
thing as an anti-neutrino, since they are neutral particles without any 
smaller composing factors and also we've never seen two interact to form a 
photon.

comments.author: Nachiketh Rao

comments.text:
+Comraderob1 Well in Feynman diagrams (Quantum Field Theory) a positive 
charge going towards an interaction is identical to a negative charge going 
away backwards in time.

Take this example:

A positron and an electron approach each other and annihilate producing 
photons. This is one picture of the interaction.

Another mathematically equal interaction would be ONE electron flying 
towards a point then turning around and going backwards in time. That is 
the positron would be an electron going the opposite direction in the 
dimension of time.

This neatly accounts for the fact that positrons and electrons attract and 
electrons and electrons repel. The photons bouncing back and forth create 
the repulsion between electrons. When a positron and electron interact the 
photons still cause repulsion but time is flowing in reverse from each 
particle's perspective. Therefore as time moves forward from the other's 
perspective time is going backwards so the particles attract.

This could mean that all positive particles are moving in one direction of 
time and all negative particles in the opposite. If a pair of the same 
particle collide that just means the particle turned around in the time 
dimension. Nothing I have ever heard of disputes this theory and in fact it 
was in my Standard Model text book by Griffiths (Elementary Particle 
Physics). It was just proposed as an interesting idea with no proof.

All Feynman diagrams have the little arrows on them and contrary to what 
Minutephysics said more than just the charge flips in anti-particles. 
Indeed all quantum numbers flip.

This would mean there are three arrows of time.

The positive arrow of time for say "positive charge." The negative arrow of 
time for "negative charge." However, there would be no way to know which 
one is which. We would only see the interaction between the two. Finally, 
the thermodynamic arrow of time that we sense because the future has more 
entropy than the past (more disorder). 

That Feynman diagrams can all be flipped like this is fairly interesting 
but I haven't heard of any experiments proving anything.

comments.author: Kendall D

comments.text:
Great channel.
Annihilation teaches us one thing: matter and antimatter is made out of 
smaller stuff. But what is 'energy', what are 'waves' of radiation. What is 
that stuff made of? Will it always be limited to equational descriptions or 
will technology ever find out? Even more peculiar is the 'quantum field' 
and also the 'Higgs field'. Excitations in a field is rather vague, but 
granted it's the best we got today. You can take it even further then: what 
is the field made of, what generates it? Physicists want to learn the truth 
of all things, they will keep looking

Mindboggling though that everything is just forcefields. Row row row your 
boat gently down the stream, merily merily merily, life is but a dream...﻿

comments.text:
This may sound stupid, but the big bang is the start of time. What if 
there's another timeline that exist which whole most matter flew forward in 
time, antimatter flew backwards through an anti time. 

Any antimatter we create would want to go in that direction of course, and 
would go backwards in time, which is physically impossible because then we 
wouldn't be able to discover antimatter. But if time like matter has a 
momentum, then antimatter wanting to go backwards would have to fight that 
momentum. Like, pretending a train on a track is time, a train moving 
forward would 1st have to decelerate, before it can accelerate in a reverse 
direction. 
Of course I'm not a physicist, so I'm sure there are plenty of flaws in my 
idea.﻿
